articles.headline: Watts, 50 Years On, Stands in Contrast to Today’s Conflicts
articles.snippet: A symbol of racial tensions after riots broke out on Aug. 11, 1965, Watts, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, has made strides in relations between the police and the community. But it is no utopia.
articles.abstract: A symbol of racial tensions after riots broke out on Aug. 11, 1965, Watts, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, has made strides in relations between the police and the community. But it is no utopia.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Donny Joubert watched the boy round the corner of the housing project holding what looked like a handgun. The barrel was pointed at him and the two officers from the Los Angeles Police Department. The boy was 10 or 11 years old, Mr. Joubert figured, and had more gleam than anger in his eyes. Mr. Joubert, a community activist who grew up in the project, shouted and lunged for the gun.

articles.headline: For Many in Spain, a Heralded Economic Recovery Feels Like a Bust
articles.snippet: The majority of the country’s new jobs are part-time and offer low wages, experts say, and some employees are expected to do hours of unpaid work.
articles.abstract: The majority of the country’s new jobs are part-time and offer low wages, experts say, and some employees are expected to do hours of unpaid work.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZARAGOZA, Spain — He used to be an interior designer, outfitting shops for one of Spain’s biggest clothing store chains.

articles.headline: Google to Reorganize as Alphabet to Keep Its Lead as an Innovator
articles.snippet: Under the new name, Alphabet, the company is signaling that it has essentially become a collection of disparate businesses.
articles.abstract: Under the new name, Alphabet, the company is signaling that it has essentially become a collection of disparate businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google was founded as a company that did Internet search. Over time, it has broadened into areas as varied as drones, pharmaceuticals and venture capital, none of which make much money, and some of which have spooked investors.

articles.headline: Outcry for Cecil the Lion Could Undercut Conservation Efforts
articles.snippet: Trophy hunting, which has been viewed under a harsh public spotlight since the killing of Cecil, a lion in Zimbabwe, is part of a complex economy that is an effective method of conservation, many wildlife experts contend.
articles.abstract: Trophy hunting, which has been viewed under a harsh public spotlight since the killing of Cecil, a lion in Zimbabwe, is part of a complex economy that is an effective method of conservation, many wildlife experts contend.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLIFANTSVLEI, South Africa — Before the two hunters from Texas had breakfast, Stewart Dorrington drove through his 12,000-acre game ranch. As the early-morning sun cast a soft glow on the landscape, turned a wintry pale brown, buffalo wandered in the tall grass and giraffes appeared in a cluster of trees.

articles.headline: With Google as Alphabet, a Bid to Dream Big Beyond Search
articles.snippet: From Google’s start, Larry Page has been afflicted with a desire for two competing corporate virtues: focus and expansiveness.
articles.abstract: From Google’s start, Larry Page has been afflicted with a desire for two competing corporate virtues: focus and expansiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Shortly after its founding, Google posted a document on its site called “Ten things we know to be true,” an effort to distill its unusual corporate culture into a succinct list of prescriptions — the 10 commandments of Googliness. Among the most-quoted of Google’s big thoughts has been that corporations should “do one thing really, really well.” Google’s one thing, the document said, was obvious: “We do search.”

articles.headline: Sundar Pichai Will Lead Google With Users in Mind
articles.snippet: The newly appointed chief executive owes his new job to his success in making Google products easier to use and thus more popular.
articles.abstract: The newly appointed chief executive owes his new job to his success in making Google products easier to use and thus more popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The technology industry is partial to dramatic, sometimes blustery, often larger-than-life top executives. Sundar Pichai will have to work hard to be ranked among that colorful crew. He sent news of his ascension to the top slot at Google — he is just the third person to officially run the search company — on Twitter, very obliquely.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Stock Buybacks Draw Scrutiny From Politicians
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton and others are asking whether there’s a need for greater regulation of stock buybacks, on which companies have spent $7 trillion since 2004.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton and others are asking whether there’s a need for greater regulation of stock buybacks, on which companies have spent $7 trillion since 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should corporate stock buybacks be regulated? Or made illegal?

articles.headline: China Devalues Its Currency as Worries Rise About Economic Slowdown
articles.snippet: The move appeared to be a response to signs that the economy was slowing too fast for comfort and could raise tensions with trading partners like the United States.
articles.abstract: The move appeared to be a response to signs that the economy was slowing too fast for comfort and could raise tensions with trading partners like the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As China contends with an economic slowdown and a stock market slump, the authorities on Tuesday sharply devalued the country’s currency, the renminbi, a move that could raise geopolitical tensions and weigh on growth elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Tentative Greek Debt Accord Might Do Little to Revive Economy
articles.snippet: The plan, outlined in a 20-hour negotiating session, would provide aid worth up to about $95 billion in exchange for harsh austerity terms.
articles.abstract: The plan, outlined in a 20-hour negotiating session, would provide aid worth up to about $95 billion in exchange for harsh austerity terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek government on Tuesday appeared to be on the verge of clinching a deal for a new international bailout worth as much as $95 billion in exchange for accepting harsh austerity terms and making sweeping changes to the way the country does business.

articles.headline: Nine Charged in Insider Trading Case Tied to Hackers
articles.snippet: The international scheme generated more than $100 million in illegal profits, and the S.E.C. is bringing a parallel lawsuit in the case.
articles.abstract: The international scheme generated more than $100 million in illegal profits, and the S.E.C. is bringing a parallel lawsuit in the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a symbiotic relationship that brought together the underbelly of Wall Street and the dark reaches of the online world.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson
